item.title: Call for Papers
item.description: Overview The goal of this workshop is to encourage and highlight novel strategies for image matching that deviate from and advance traditional formulations, with a focus on large-scale, wide-baseline matching for 3D reconstruction or pose estimation. This can be achieved by applying new technologies to sparse feature matching, or doing away with keypoints and descriptors entirely. Topics Workshop topics include (but are not limited to): Reformulating keypoint extraction and matching pipelines with deep networks.

item.title: Challenge
item.description: Introduction Local features have played a key role in a wide range of computer vision applications throughout the past 20 years, particularly since the introduction of SIFT. Despite the drastic advancements resulting from deep learning techniques, 3D reconstruction under challenging conditions remains somewhat of an outlier, as performance in small, constrained benchmarks does not necessarily translate to real-world scenarios. In practice, keypoint-based methods remain the most common solution to this problem, and techniques such as SIFT or RANSAC are still very much in use.

item.title: Leaderboard
item.description: This is a work in progress. More baselines/sequences will be added (by the organizers) over the next 1-2 weeks. Minor alterations to the test pipeline will happen before the final release of the test data and evaluation procedure. The 2019 edition of the challenge contains two tasks over two datasets: Task P1: Stereo maching in the ‘Phototourism’ dataset Task P2: Multi-view reconstruction in the ‘Phototourism’ dataset Task L1: Stereo maching in the ‘London’ dataset Glossary For details about the datasets, tasks, and evaluation metrics, please refer to the datasets page.
